description: From Middle English demure, demwre, of uncertain formation, but probably from Old French meur (Modern French mûr) from Latin mātūrus. The "de-" is "of", as in "of maturity".

entries.meaning: (usually of women) Quiet, modest, reserved, sober, or serious.
examples: She is a demure young lady.

entries.meaning: Affectedly modest, decorous, or serious; making a show of gravity.
examples: Miss Lizzy, I have no doubt, would be as demure and coquettish, as if ten winters more had gone over her head.

verbs.description: demure (third-person singular simple present demures, present participle demuring, simple past and past participle demured)
